content.text: Python - Join Sets
Join Sets
There are several ways to join two or more sets in Python.
content.html: There are several ways to join two or more sets in Python.

content.text: The union() and update() methods joins all items from both sets.
content.html: The union() and update() methods joins all items from both sets.

content.text: The intersection() method keeps ONLY the duplicates.
content.html: The intersection() method keeps ONLY the duplicates.

content.text: The difference() method keeps the items from the first set that are not in the other set(s).
content.html: The difference() method keeps the items from the first set that are not in the other set(s).

content.text: The symmetric_difference() method keeps all items EXCEPT the duplicates.
content.html: The symmetric_difference() method keeps all items EXCEPT the duplicates.

content.text: Union
The union() method returns a new set with all items from both sets.
content.html: The union() method returns a new set with all items from both sets.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"a", "b", "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}

set3 = set1.union(set2)
print(set3)

content.text: You can use the | operator instead of the union() method, and you will get the same result.
content.html: You can use the | operator instead of the union() method, and you will get the same result.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"a", "b", "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}

set3 = set1 | set2
print(set3)

content.text: Join Multiple Sets
All the joining methods and operators can be used to join multiple sets.
content.html: All the joining methods and operators can be used to join multiple sets.

content.text: When using a method, just add more sets in the parentheses, separated by commas:
content.html: When using a method, just add more sets in the parentheses, separated by commas:

content.code_html:
set1 = {"a", "b", "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}
set3 = {"John", "Elena"}
set4 = {"apple", "bananas", "cherry"}

myset = set1.union(set2, set3, set4)
print(myset)

content.text: When using the | operator, separate the sets with more | operators:
content.html: When using the | operator, separate the sets with more | operators:

content.code_html:
set1 = {"a", "b", "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}
set3 = {"John", "Elena"}
set4 = {"apple", "bananas", "cherry"}

myset = set1 | set2 | set3 |set4
print(myset)

content.text: Join a Set and a Tuple
The union() method allows you to join a set with other data types, like lists or tuples.
content.html: The union() method allows you to join a set with other data types, like lists or tuples.

content.text: The result will be a set.
content.html: The result will be a set.

content.code_html:
x = {"a", "b", "c"}
y = (1, 2, 3)

z = x.union(y)
print(z)

content.text: Note: The | operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the union() method.
content.html: Note: The  | operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the  union() method.

content.text: Update
The update() method inserts all items from one set into another.
content.html: The update() method inserts all items from one set into another.

content.text: The update() changes the original set, and does not return a new set.
content.html: The update() changes the original set, and does not return a new set.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"a", "b" , "c"}
set2 = {1, 2, 3}

set1.update(set2)
print(set1)

content.text: Note: Both union() and update() will exclude any duplicate items.
content.html: Note: Both union() and update() will exclude any duplicate items.

content.text: Intersection
Keep ONLY the duplicates
content.html: Keep ONLY the duplicates

content.text: The intersection() method will return a new set, that only contains the items that are present in both sets.
content.html: The intersection() method will return a new set, that only contains the items that are present in both sets.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set3 = set1.intersection(set2)
print(set3)

content.text: You can use the & operator instead of the intersection() method, and you will get the same result.
content.html: You can use the & operator instead of the intersection() method, and you will get the same result.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set3 = set1 & set2
print(set3)

content.text: Note: The & operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the intersection() method.
content.html: Note: The & operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the intersection() method.

content.text: The intersection_update() method will also keep ONLY the duplicates, but it will change the original set instead of returning a new set.
content.html: The intersection_update() method will also keep ONLY the duplicates, but it will change the original set instead of returning a new set.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set1.intersection_update(set2)

print(set1)

content.text: The values True and 1 are considered the same value. The same goes for False and 0 .
content.html: The values True and 1 are considered the same value. The same goes for False and 0.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", 1,  "banana", 0, "cherry"}
set2 = {False, "google", 1, "apple", 2, True}

set3 = set1.intersection(set2)

print(set3)

content.text: Difference
The difference() method will return a new set that will contain only the items from the first set that are not present in the other set.
content.html: The difference() method will return a new set that will contain only the items from the first set that are not present in the other set.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set3 = set1.difference(set2)

print(set3)

content.text: You can use the - operator instead of the difference() method, and you will get the same result.
content.html: You can use the - operator instead of the difference() method, and you will get the same result.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set3 = set1 - set2
print(set3)

content.text: Note: The - operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the difference() method.
content.html: Note: The - operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the difference() method.

content.text: The difference_update() method will also keep the items from the first set that are not in the other set, but it will change the original set instead of returning a new set.
content.html: The difference_update() method will also keep the items from the first set that are not in the other set, but it will change the original set instead of returning a new set.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set1.difference_update(set2)

print(set1)

content.text: Symmetric Differences
The symmetric_difference() method will keep only the elements that are NOT present in both sets.
content.html: The symmetric_difference() method will keep only the elements that are NOT present in both sets.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set3 = set1.symmetric_difference(set2)

print(set3)

content.text: You can use the ^ operator instead of the symmetric_difference() method, and you will get the same result.
content.html: You can use the ^ operator instead of the symmetric_difference() method, and you will get the same result.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set3 = set1 ^ set2
print(set3)

content.text: Note: The ^ operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the symmetric_difference() method.
content.html: Note: The ^ operator only allows you to join sets with sets, and not with other data types like you can with the symmetric_difference() method.

content.text: The symmetric_difference_update() method will also keep all but the duplicates, but it will change the original set instead of returning a new set.
content.html: The symmetric_difference_update() method will also keep all but the duplicates, but it will change the original set instead of returning a new set.

content.code_html:
set1 = {"apple", "banana", "cherry"}
set2 = {"google", "microsoft", "apple"}

set1.symmetric_difference_update(set2)

print(set1)

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is a correct syntax for joining set1 and set2 into set3 ?
content.html: What is a correct syntax for joining set1 and set2 into set3?
